passages.text: Key Sector Themes & Conference Survival Guide

We highlight the KEY THEMES investors should consider when stock- picking in Beverages & Tobacco during the Back- to- School Conference Season. In this report we share KEY QUESTIONS for management and a stock- by- stock guidance summary. In Beverages, Q2 earnings were mixed, with volume misses in beer/soft drinks severely punished, however, with business models for both intact, any signs of an improving Q3 (esp. LatAm) should be supportive. We like Carlsberg and ABInBev, with the latter likely to benefit from a new buyback with its Q3 results. In Spirits, clarity on tariffs is enabling investors to focus on fundamentals. Although near- term trading visibility remains low, prudent Campari estimates leave them well- placed to perform, while Diageo and Pernod's control of the controllables should limit downside risk. Tobacco remains our preferred subsector. Encouraging modern oral growth and increasing enforcement against US illicit vape should support most stocks. BAT is top- pick followed by PM and Imperial.
1. Current sector themes/areas of debate.
2. Key questions to ask management on a stock-by-stock basis.
3. Guidance summaries by company with Citi and consensus estimates & recent market trends, geographic exposure and valuation metrics.

In BEVERAGES, investor debate is likely to focus on: 1) Consumer backdrop - despite no incremental deterioration and resilient on- trade momentum, we are yet to see a material up- tick in underlying consumer demand with footfall in out- of- home venues not necessarily translating into consumption; 2) European weather trends - although not universal, weather trends have generally been supportive through Q2 and early Q3 with all eyes on August/September data; 3) LatAm trading - we believe concerns around consumer resilience in key LatAm markets are overdone, with Q2 weakness driven by a combination of weather, price positioning and macro; 4) Tariff clarity for Spirits - with China Cognac tariffs now settled, and a 15% rate on EU spirits, we believe further downside risks are limited. OVERALL, we prefer BEER near- term, as well as GCEP. In Spirits, on- going uncertainty around the timing of pace of recovery means fundamental catalysts remain absent for now.

In TOBACCO, investor debate is likely to focus on: 1) US illicit vapour enforcement - increased regulation around illicit vapour products will be a benefit to both US combustibles and legal vapour. As such, any early signs of a meaningful clampdown will remain a key topic; 2) Can Modern Oral momentum continue? With BAT's Velo and Imperial's Zone joining the more established ZYN (PM) and On! (MO) brands in driving sustained impressive category growth, all eyes will be on both short- term scanp data trends in the US and the long- term category potential. BAT is our TOP- PICK across our Beverages & Tobacco coverage. We also remain supportive of HILIP MORRIS and IMPERIAL.

In BEVERAGES, we expect near- term investor questioning/debate and management commentary to be concentrated around:

The consumer is still subdued BUT no obvious further deterioration: Although the absence of any incremental deterioration in consumption in Developed Markets was in some sense reassuring through Q2 earnings season, there is little sign of a pick- up. On a positive note, a number of companies - Heineken, CCEP, ABlnBev, Campari - all noted an improvement in traffic in onpremise/away- from- home outlets in Europe and the US. However, as Campari's CEO pointed out, although footfall is good in bars and restaurants, this is not necessarily translating into a recovery in consumption in these occasions to historic norms. Many consumers are still dealing with the inflationary squeeze on disposable income and moderating spend by opting to have "two drinks instead of three."
Conclusion: The consumer continues to bumble along the bottom, but a number of stocks called out some positive signs of pick- up in the on- trade. (+VE Carlsberg, Campari, Heineken)

Is European weather proving to be a support?: Investors/analysts came into Q2 earnings season expected to see clear signs of an uplift in European Beverage volumes from recent better (June/July) weather. However, evidence of a clear pick- up has been mixed. Heineken's early print set a cautious tone with European volumes missing consensus estimates. However, we believe the relative weakness at Heineken owed more to the retailer disputes (some of which were only resolved towards the end of the period) rather than a lack of weather- related support. Importantly CCEP noted that good weather in June and July had a big positive impact on trading, especially in the away- from- home channel, with the GB market a standout performer. Campari also noted a strong start to aperitif season with big peak in June and encouraging start to Q3. This is consistent with our latest Weather tracker report (SEE: European Beverages: Citi Weather Watch: UK and Nordics support to CARL & RBREW. Broadly neutral trends elsewhere, with CCH weaker.). However, the weather benefit is not universal in Europe, with CCH highlighting the weather in Central & Eastern Europe had been more mixed Q3 to date.
Conclusion: Weather in Northern Europe (esp. GB) and Italy is helping, driving strong Q2 exit rates and a good start to Q3. (+VE Carlsberg, Campari, Royal Unibrew)

LatAm trading in focus BUT concerns overdone?: Tariff uncertainty has clearly been weighing on consumer sentiment across LatAm through H1 25. However, investor worries around a potential worsening situation were elevated by Heineken and ABlnBev Q2 results prints. Heineken noted its Brazil business was impacted by self- inflicted destocking as well as softer consumer sentiment in Q2 and this cautionary tone was amplified by ABlnBev's big Q2 volume miss in Brazil. Both stocks wobbled, suffering a sharp pullback as investors questioned whether an inflection point had been reached in what had been a relatively resilient region for beer volumes up until this point. We think the reaction/concerns are overdone. Although we accept the LatAm backdrop is likely to remain subdued, ABlnBev acknowledged in post Q2 results meetings

that although consumer sentiment is still weak, there had NOT been a notable delta in Q2 vs. Q1. Moreover, management noted that the main drivers of its poor \(- 9\%\) Q2 Brazilian volume fall were 1) poor weather at the end of May/early June; 2) price gap issues with the Heineken portfolio (which corrected in early July following Heineken's MSD price increase) and then only 3) the macro environment.
Conclusion: LatAm is clearly not humming BUT worries about the scale of a consumer retreat from beer/beverages is probably overdone. We expect Q3 momentum will be better. (+VE for ABlnBev)

Tariff clarity emerging with \(15\%\) EU tariff discounted in Spirits stocks: There has clearly been a lot of news around tariffs over the last few weeks, be that the incrementally positive news around Chinese Cognac tariffs or more recent moves by the Trump Administration to agree trade deals or impose new tariffs on specific countries. In terms of the latter, it is worth noting that European spirits company guidance has now moved to apply a \(15\%\) tariff on EU imports to the US. As a result, if a more favorable terms agreement (or even a spirits exemption) were to be reached in the coming months, the risk to estimates at Diageo, Campari, Rémy and Pernod is skewed to the upside.
In TOBACCO, we expect near- term investor questioning/debate and management commentary to be concentrated around:

Signs of clampdown on US Illicit vape encouraging: As we expected coming into Q2 earnings season, much of the focus in tobacco would be around the potential clampdown on illicit vape imports into the US by the authorities. Not only is this potentially beneficial to the legal vapour offering in the market like BAT's Vuse brand but it is also likely to be supportive for the core US combustibles market for BAT and Altria. Although it is still too early to see a positive impact on off- take trends on the ground, BAT noted regulation against illicit vapes was underway in 18 states, while both Altria and BAT noted there was a clear desire by the authorities to get rid of these products. Moreover, there is evidence that key illicit brands like Geekbar & Elfbar have struggled to reach the shelf of late, although out- of- stocks have generally been absorbed by other illicit offerings. Nevertheless, the wind is clearly beginning to blow in the right direction and both BAT and Altria are "cautiously optimistic" about go- forward enforcement, especially if there were to be more active targeting of the c.15 key importers/wholesaler in the US. However, both companies acknowledge, real success can only be achieved alongside a consistent and more rapid approach to the legal PMTA authorisation process.
Conclusion: Illicit clampdown/disruption is likely to intensify underpinned a further re- rating of US exposed Tobacco stocks. (+VE BAT, Altria, Imperial)

Can Modern Oral momentum continue? Modern Oral has been the key growth category (alongside illicit vapour) in the US nicotine market due to significant growth in Velo (BATS) and Zone (Imperial) as well as continued growth for the more established ZYN (PMI) and On! (Altria) brands. After a disappointing Q2 ZYN print in the US due to less restocking than expected, all eyes will be on company comments and on- going scanner data to see if consumer off- take trends for ZYN and the wider category remains resilient.

Short- term - what are the key questions?
Can you talk a bit on current trading in Q3- to- date? What have been the main callouts from a current trading standpoint?

Tariffs are obviously a key topic and although you have minimal direct exposure to US import tariffs given your local production footprint, how are you thinking about the second- order effects on some of your key markets?

Your US business has seen a notable repositioning in recent years in the wake of the Bud Light situation. Can you give some context to how you have repositioned the portfolio and what you see as the key drivers of performance in the US?

Can you talk to current momentum for Busch Light and Michelob Ultra? How is Bud Light performing and to what extent do you expect the brand to recover? At what level of share are you expecting to stabilise in the mid- term?

Can you talk to the Busch Light Apple innovation and how that performed? Given it was a limited edition and is now off the market, how should we think about Busch innovations going forward? Do you have further limited editions in the pipeline?

Still on the US, you clearly stepped up your focus on cost control in the US. What have been the key drivers of this? Given you have now lapped the wholesaler support measures in the US and as such the EBITDA base going forward is normalized, how should we think about opportunities for further cost management and efficiencies for FY25/26E?
Can you take a step back on the US business and outline your strategy going forward given the changes you have seen in recent years?

Moving on from the US, can you speak to the current trading in China? Q2 volumes were down \(- 7\%\) and although this is weak, it was a sequential improvement on Q1. Are you able to talk to current trading in Q3- to- date and whether you have seen a continued improvement?

Can you talk to the channel mix in China, given on- trade has been under more pressure due to the tough macro backdrop while the off- trade has seen relatively more support? What are you doing on the ground to capture the shifting momentum into the off- trade channel? Are you expanding into the off- trade more than you have previously?

Still on China but moving to talk about geographic mix, can you comment on the regional performances with Central/West outperforming the East? How does this impact your business? What are you doing to mitigate these headwinds?

Can you comment to the product mix development in China, with premium under more pressure? How is your portfolio positioned in China and how do you expect the remainder of FY25E to play out for premium?
- How important has the roll-out and adoption of the BEES platform been in capturing demand as China?

- Can you comment on your South American markets and trading in Q3-to-date? What are the main markets to call out? How should we think about FY25 from a volume standpoint? Can you also talk to the pricing environment in key South American markets?

- In Brazil, can you talk to the pricing competition you are seeing in the market and how your volumes are performing across the price segments? Q2 volumes were weaker than expected and you referenced pricing taken in April; can you comment on whether competition has followed and how you expect volumes to develop in H2?
- You also mentioned unsupportive weather trends in Brazil, particularly so in June. Are you able to give us some colour on Q3 trading for July/August and how weather trends have turned out?
- Can you talk to the ongoing success of BEES in Brazil and latest digital initiatives you have pushed? How is momentum for Ze Delivery developing?

- Is there anything to call out from the tax environment in Brazil given there have been moving parts around tax reforms in recent years and IOC/state tax changes? Are there any key developments we should be keeping an eye on?
- Mexico volumes in Q2 were up LSD which was in-part driven by the Easter impact. Can you comment on Q3 trading and your expectations for the remainder of FY25E?
- Can you talk to the consumer environment in Mexico and whether you are seeing any meaningful macro headwinds? Are you able to pick out some key brand performances?
- Looking to Europe, can you comment on the state of the consumer and what has been driving your relative outperformance?
- How are you thinking about Q3 in Europe given it is a key trading period for the region, and you are lapping soft weather comps? How has momentum been in June/July so far across your key markets?
- More broadly, can you comment on any events in FY25 across your global portfolio and any key activations you are planning?

- Elsewhere, are there any major areas to call out from a trading standpoint that are particularly strong or weak? Or are there any areas where the underlying trends have changed noticeably from FY24?
- Can you talk about Michelob Ultra and how the various market launches have been performing?

- Are you able to talk to the pricing landscape in FY25E and what your expectations are? When can we expect to see pricing being taken and is this likely to be broad-based or selective? Are you able to give a rough ballpark of where you see pricing ending up? Is it fair to assume LSD%?
- How do you think about the prospects for COGS deflation in FY25E? Where are you seeing easing COGS headwinds and are there any key pressure points to call
out where you are still seeing elevated prices? How important a driver will transactional FX moves be to LatAm margin moves over the next 12- months?
Can you talk about the success of Cutwater Spirits? Who is the core consumer? What's the occasion? What is the opportunity for the brand outside the US?
What else is coming through the pipeline in US to pick- up slack when pre- mixed cocktails inevitably roll- over like Hard Seltzers have? How quickly can you innovate and get to market now?
Are you able to comment on your capital allocation priorities and the outlook for share buybacks going forward?
Can we expect buybacks going forward to be of a similar magnitude and with a degree of regularity or is the near- term focus the potential for greater participation in any further placing by Altria?
What are the main factors underpinning your organic EBITDA growth guidance of \(+4\%\) to \(+8\%\) ? How do we think about volume vs. value driven growth?

You're clearly prioritising further expansion into the Beyond Beer category to drive growth as well as access more drinking occasions. You indicated that the Beyond Beer segment currently accounted for around c.\$1.5bn or c.3% of group revenue. How big could this category become for you on a 3- to- 5- year view?

Michel Doukeris (CEO) talked at the investor seminar last September about how beer was gaining share of total beverage alcohol globally, driven by Emerging Market trends. That dynamic is much less clear in Developed Markets. Can you stabilise your volume and value share position relative to wines and spirits in major Developed Market like the US on a sustainable basis going forward?

LatAm volumes have been strong for a while. What is driving the share of throat gains you've been seeing in those markets and how confident are you in the sustainability of volume growth going forward and the affordability of beer in EMs?

Digital transformation is clearly an area you've been investing in and building expertise in for a while. It appears that you have some industry lead capabilities. Which areas do you think need more work and where do you already think you have a competitive advantage and how should we think about overall levels of digital investment going forward? Stable, increasing as a percent of sales?

As you continue the rollout of the BEES system, does that require incremental investment as you move into new markets or is it just as simple as turning it on in new territories? Are the potential benefits of BEES from a customer and volume/value uplift standpoint as significant in Developed Markets as they have been across Emerging Markets in areas like LatAm?
BEES marketplace revenues are clearly dilutive to margins. How much bigger would BEES need to get in Revenue terms before you might consider breaking it out?
You've clearly done a lot of work on your digital transformation agenda in many different parts of your business. Can you talk a little more about the additional
B2B tools within the BEEs platform, especially the provision of banking services to your customers?
In Brazil, how do you go about getting your fair share of the premium segment? Heineken has really made significant headway and gains in this area in recent years. Can you catch- up?
How many markets are you in worldwide with Ze Delivery/TA Da and what proportion of your volume footprint could this business potentially cover overtime?

You've flagged the opportunity to continue to drive growth in China in the premium and super- premium segment of the beer market going forward driven by the growth of the middle- class population. How do you think about the levels of growth between those 2 segments with competition intensifying in premium? CRB in partnership with Heineken are rolling out their premium portfolio aggressively. Are you seeing any pressure on Budweiser consumption occasions from Heineken? What is your current share of premium and super- premium?

What do you see as key opportunities within ABInBev from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the beer industry?

Short- term - what are the key questions?

Can you comment on current underlying trends across your key markets? Is there anything to call out since Q2 results from a current trading standpoint? How has momentum been across the July/August relative to last year?
Tariffs are obviously a key topic and although you have minimal direct exposure to US import tariffs, how are you thinking about the second- order effects on some of your key markets?

Can we talk about China and the current consumer environment you are seeing there? Q2 volumes were flat and sequentially weaker on Q1; how are you performing relative to the market? Can you talk to the key drivers of this outperformance and how you see the remainder of FY25 playing out in China?
You have relatively consistently managed to outperform the industry in China by c.4- 5ppts over the past couple of years. Can you comment on the drivers behind your consistency in delivery in China?
Can you comment on inventory levels in China and how the summer sell- in has been in July/August? Is there anything to call out from a wholesaler stock standpoint?

Can you comment to your regional performances within China and where you have seen growth coming from? How have Big Cities performed relative to the rest of the country and how have you targeted growth in these markets?
Can you flesh out how premium has performed relative to mainstream? And within that, which brands have been the standout performers and which have seen more subdued momentum?

Regarding channel performance, are you able to flesh out how the on- trade has been performing and can you comment on your move to prioritise the off- trade given the current weaker consumer environment?

Still on China, can you comment on your strategy to go deeper into existing cities? What are you planning to do in key cities to solidify market share gains? How should we think about further expansion into new cities?

How are premiumisation trends holding up in India? Are you able to comment on the strength of the consumer and the significance of India as a key growth engine for you in the short- term? What brands are driving growth?
How should we think about India in the near- term given you now have full control of the business? What are the near- term focuses?
Can you comment on capacity in the near- term in India and whether there are any constraints currently? Are you able to give some colour on capex plans to cater for solid market growth?
Are you able to give some colour on the heavier monsoon rainfall you saw in July and how you expect this to impact Q3 performance?

In Vietnam, you over- index in mainstream which has clearly benefitted from the macro slowdown, although H1 saw weaker momentum in Central Vietnam where you have a strong presence. Are you able to give some background to the weaker H1 and what the main drivers behind that were? How do you see the remainder of FY25E playing out?
Still on Vietnam, can you comment to the different trends you are seeing across the country and how this impacts your business? What are you doing to expand your presence in the south?
In both Vietnam and India, can you comment on the favourable demographics of both markets and how these play into your mid- term growth algorithm?
Again, for both Vietnam and India, can you talk to the competitive environment you are seeing in these markets and comment on the level of promo intensity?
Elsewhere in Asia, is there anything to call out on other markets such as Laos and Cambodia? Why has there been such weakness in the Cambodia soft drinks business?
Are you able to talk about the competitive environment in Cambodia and the increased competition you are seeing from local players?
In Central & Eastern Europe, can you comment on your expectations across key markets as consumer pressure persists but perhaps may see some moderation?
Are you expecting a meaningful degree of divergence across your Europe footprint?

Kazakhstan was notably weak in Q1 and recovered in Q2; are you able to comment on the business there and the underlying trends you are seeing in the market? How should we think about portfolio optimization?

Still on Kazakhstan, your Pepsi business there is facing some delays, and you are now likely to operate with co- packers initially with production coming on- stream later in FY26. Can you talk us through the moving parts here and why this is developing more slowly than expected? How should we think about the impact of the partnership on the P&L in FY26E?

Can you comment on Western Europe and your outlook for FY25E? Clearly the loss of San Miguel has been a notable headwind, but can you comment to some of the key brand performances on the Continent and how you see H2 shaping up?

In the UK, can you comment on the extent to which you will be able to fill the void lost from San Miguel? What are you doing on the ground to mitigate the impact with brands such as Brooklyn, Poretti and 1664? What is the timeline for you to recover the lost volumes?
Still on the UK, can you comment on the Britvic UK performance in H1?

Are you able to give some colour on the early decisions you have made with Britvic regarding some contract exits in France and some changes to the wider International business? What was your rationale for the changes?

More generally on Britvic, can you talk about the strategic logic behind the acquisition (completed in January 2025) and how this fits with your \(4 - 6\%\) midterm group OSG growth targets? What, in your view, is the mid- term growth algorithm for the business and what are the key drivers?
What areas of revenue synergy opportunity do you see between Carlsberg and Britvic?

Elsewhere, within Western Europe, volumes in the Nordics in Q1 were flat; are you able to comment on underlying trends across the Nordic markets and to what extent you have seen an impact from US brand boycotting in Denmark on your Coke business?
On France, how should we think about the recovery there and what are you doing to regain momentum after a difficult 2024?
Is there anything else to call out on specific markets? How is momentum in Poland and Switzerland? You commented on weaker weather trends in Poland in July- how has this since developed?

Can you talk to your pricing strategy for FY25E? Where are you with pricing for the year? Have you seen any change in the pricing environment generally across Europe? Is it more difficult to land pricing now than it has been historically?
Can we talk about COGS and what you are seeing in terms of commodity prices and more generally input costs? How should we think about the moving parts for FY25/26E?
Can you talk to the puts and takes for the \(+3 - 5\%\) organic EBIT growth guidance for FY25E which you narrowed at the Q2 print? What assumptions are you baking in around China, Vietnam macro etc.?
The \(+3 - 5\%\) EBIT growth guidance implies a decent pick- up in H2; what are the key drivers behind this acceleration and what gives you confidence in being able to deliver against this metric?
Can you talk to your LNA performance and what has been the driving components behind the business? Where are the key opportunities for growth?
Can you talk to your near- term capex plans and what your major capacity expansion projects are currently? How are you expanding in China? How will you address the supply chain in India?

At FY23 results you updated your mid- term guidance to organic revenue growth of \(+4\%\) to \(+6\%\) (previously \(+3\%\) to \(+5\%\) ) with organic operating profit to grow ahead. What gives you confidence in achieving this and what were the key drivers behind the upgraded metrics from the existing Sail '27 framework?
What are the key areas of difference when it comes to the core drivers behind the mid- term growth targets relative to the previous Sail '27 framework?
What is a reasonable run- rate of volume growth in the mid- term? How can we expect the make- up of the \(+4\%\) to \(+6\%\) top- line growth in terms of volumes vs price/mix?

With the new mid- term targets, you are now leading the market in terms of European growth outlook. Can you comment on your competitive edge and why you believe you can outperform your peers in Europe?

Can you comment on your partnership with PepsiCo and how you expect this relationship to develop in the mid- term? You announced the new partnership in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in September; can we expect further geographies to come into play in the coming years? Can you talk to the benefits of partnering with PepsiCo and why Carlsberg stands out as a bottler- of- choice?

Can you give more colour on your Beyond Beer strategy and how you see that panning out in the mid- term? Would you consider M&A outside of the beer category like some of your peers have/are doing, e.g. in wine & spirits?
You have earmarked China, India and Vietnam as three key pillars behind midterm growth. Can you go into detail on each market and expand on the opportunities you see for meaningful growth?

What do you think is the right level of sustainable volume growth for your Chinese business over the next 3 to 5 years? Talk a little about the building blocks of that growth rate between your local brands like Wuzu and international premium brands? What risks do you see to this strategy from the roll- out of Heineken by the Heineken/CRE JV? How much further has your 'Big City Strategy' got to run in the market?

Talk about the investment you've made in IT systems in recent years, the success of Carl's Shop from a B2B standpoint? How have you enhanced your consumer analytic tools? What more needs to be done in these areas? Where do you think you're lagging peers or ahead of other FMCGs? Which regions/markets are ahead/behind the curve in this regard?

The DraughtMaster roll- out was clearly impacted by the pandemic. How big an opportunity do you think is yet to be realised from this initiative? What proportion of your outlets currently use DraughtMaster technology?

Looking to the longer- term, maybe 3- 5 years forward plus, what category or growth opportunity or market are you most excited about in the business and perhaps in your mind isn't getting its fair share of attention when you talk to investors and analysts?
Similarly, what does taking control of the Kronenbourg brand in the UK add to your business there medium- term?

What do you see as key opportunities within Carlsberg from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that, what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the beer industry?

Short- term - what are the key questions?

For H1, you delivered organic EBIT growth ahead of expectations at \(+7.4\%\) despite some well- flagged headwinds you faced in Europe around retailer tensions. With the \(+4\%\) to \(+8\%\) FY guidance range reiterated, can you talk to the puts and takes for the upper/lower end of this range and how we should expect H2 to evolve?

Can you talk us through your strategic thinking around sales and marketing investments in the near- term? Can you talk us through the priorities around short- term margin performance and long- term return from higher investments?
Can you talk about transactional FX and the importance within your EBIT growth guidance? What are the main moving parts behind the transactional FX impact?
Can you remind us of where you are with your commodity hedges for 2025 and 2026?
Can you talk a bit on current trading in Q3- to- date? Are there any markets or brands to call out from a current trading standpoint?
Which regions do you think will be the key drivers of group top- line delivery in H2? How should we think about volume momentum moving into Q3/Q4? Is there anything to note from a comp perspective?

In Europe, H1 was significantly impacted by the retailer tensions you faced in France, Netherlands, Germany and Spain. Can you give some context behind the moving parts here and why these came about? Is there anything you would do differently regarding your stance on pricing with the key retailers?

Can you talk to the impact of weather year- to- date, given you are lapping poor summer weather in both 2023/24, and trends have been notably better this year? To this effect, can you comment on the performances within the on- trade vs off- trade across your key European markets?
Weather aside, can you comment on the state of the consumer in Europe and the underlying trends you are seeing around consumption and premiumisation?
Cruzcampo has had an impressive rise in the UK; can you talk to the driving factors behind its success and whether there are other key markets to keep an eye on for the brand?
Are there any other markets in Europe you would like to call out from a current trading standpoint?

Can we talk about Vietnam and the underlying trends you are seeing there? Q1 was strong, driven by a solid TET performance and you continued to see share gains in a growing market through Q2. Can you flesh out the moving parts
behind the ongoing solid performance there? How has the on- trade performed relative to the off- trade?

How has your performance in premium/mainstream been in Vietnam? How has the group performed in Q3- to- date? What about the competitive situation? Can you talk to the promo environment and your performance relative to Carlsberg?
Can you provide some colour on macro trends in Vietnam in what has been a volatile economic backdrop? How should we be thinking about second- order effects from US tariffs?
Are you happy with current inventory levels in Vietnam and what is your outlook for H2?
Elsewhere in Asia, are there any major call outs? Can you comment on the current trading in China and India?

In India, you saw a marked pick- up in Q2 after a weaker Q1 where you saw a pause in production in one of the major states. Can you flesh out the current supply chain situation in India and whether you expect constraints to continue through the remainder of FY25E?
Can you talk generally to the India business in the short- term and how you are targeting capex in what is a difficult operating environment?
Can you comment on the underlying trends you are seeing in India and talk to the premiumisation opportunity in the market?

On China can you help us understand the impact China is having on the P&L now please? Is the JV now starting to contribute more meaningfully to EBIT both via the license arrangement as well as associates?
Can you talk to the performance of the Heineken brand in China and how you see your footprint in CRB outlets developing in the near- term?
In the Americas, can you comment on recent trends in key markets Brazil and Mexico? Can you talk about your performance relative to each market? How is the premium portfolio performing?
Tariffs are obviously a key topic and although you have minimal direct exposure to US import tariffs, how are you thinking about the second- order effects on some of your key markets?
Can you add some colour to the tax environment in Brazil given there have been some moving parts in recent years?
What has been the impact from increased promo intensity in the economy segment from Petropolis? Why does it appear that you are being impacted harder by this competitive environment than ABlnBev?
Can you talk about the pricing environment in Brazil? How is the promo intensity in the economy segment faring?

In Brazil, brand Heineken and Amstel have been strong growth drivers for you. Can you comment on Q3 trading to- date and how much room for growth there is for these brands? What have been the driving factors behind the rise in these brands?
Can you comment on current trading in the US?
In AMEE, can you comment on the doubling in organic EBIT in H1 25? Can you give some colour behind the transformed cost base you reference at the Q2/H1 print? How has this evolved?
What are the current underlying market trends in Nigeria and South Africa? Can you provide some colour on these markets and how you see FY25 developing?

Can you comment on the current trading backdrop in South Africa, where you saw a stabilization in Q2? How should we think about momentum as we move into H2? Can you comment on the ongoing integration of Distell and how that is developing?

Are you able to talk us through the moving parts of the Nigerian Breweries rights issue last year and your rationale for participating in that? What will this mean for below the line other financial charges?
Are there any other key markets to comment on? Ethiopia, South- East Asia, other LatAm markets?
Can you comment on pricing in FY25E? Where are you with pricing negotiations across your footprint?
Can you talk to current trading in the pub business in the UK? What are the key trends to be aware of?
Moreover, can you comment on your commitment to invest c.40m into Star Pubs in 2025? What are the key focal areas?

Can we focus in on some of the brands you are most excited about within your portfolio? Cruzcampo has been a strong performer recently; can you talk to the drivers behind the success here? What other brands are you excited about in your portfolio for the shirt- term?

Can you talk to Heineken O.O and how trading momentum has been year- to- date? Volumes were flat in H1; can you provide some colour behind the key moving parts in this? How should we think about low/no- alcohol going forward?
How is Heineken O.O performing in the US?

Can you comment on the Evergreen programme (this is the strategy aiming to deliver superior and balanced growth) and add some colour (quantitative and or qualitative) as to the efficiencies you hope to gain in FY25E? What are going to be the key focus areas to drive cost savings?
Talk about how corporate culture has evolved to date as a function of the Evergreen programme?

Can you talk to the Distell acquisition (2023) and what the vision is for the company under your ownership? What have you been doing since the acquisition and what impact is the operation having on your broader business?
Medium/long- term – what are the key questions?

You set out your Evergreen 2025 strategy at the group Capital Markets Day in December 2022. Can we go into a bit more detail on some of the initiatives you're undertaking to deliver on your mid- term targets?
- How important a role will digitalisation have in this process?
- Can you talk to the level of reinvestment we can expect to see from the cost savings?

Carlsberg increased organic sales growth guidance of \(+4\%\) to \(+6\%\) in early 2024. Do you believe this is a level that Heineken can also achieve? What sets you above competition in the mid-term and why is Heineken more attractive than peers to deliver on mid-term growth?
Can you talk about your mid- term vision for Heineken Silver? How important do you expect the brand to be to the group? Is it cannibalising the Heineken brand?
What are you most excited about from the changes the Evergreen programme has/is making to the group? Is it the on- going strength of the Heineken brand, O.O., beyond beer products?

Talk about the investment you've made in IT systems in recent years? What more needs to be done in this area, particularly in a post- COVID 'new normal' trading environment? Where do you think you're lagging peers or ahead of other FMCGs? Which regions/markets are ahead/behind the curve in this regard?

Can you talk about you view on current key growth markets, such as Brazil, Mexico, Vietnam and how you see these markets developing in the mid- term? What trends or consumption patterns do you expect as these markets begin to mature?

What do you see as key opportunities within Heineken from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the beer industry?

Looking to the longer- term, maybe 3- 5 years forward plus, what category or growth opportunity or market are you most excited about in the business and perhaps in your mind isn't getting its fair share of attention when you talk to investors and analysts?

Short- term - what are the key questions?
Can you talk a bit on current trading in Q3- to- date - have trends continued in July/August in a similar way to Q2? Can you comment on your share performance across your categories and regions?
What are the key regions and/or categories which excite you going forward? Where do you think growth will come from in the short- term?
Can you run us through your Northern European markets and what underlying trends you are seeing there? Are there any areas of particular strength or weakness in terms of current trading?

Finland volumes in H1 were weak, impacted both by the strike in Q1 and the poor weather in May/June. Can you comment on the underlying momentum in the business in July/August and to what extent you have seen a rebound in volumes?
You have previously spoken to increased footfall in discounters relative to supermarkets and the negative impact on mix this has had on your business. Is this a trend you are still seeing?

Can you comment on the on- trade weakness you are still seeing in Northern Europe? Are there any particular markets where this weakness is more pronounced? How are you mitigating the impact from this?
Can you talk about the acquired local brands from Pernod, and how early integration has been evolving?
Can you talk us through the Norway business and the planned brewery closure? What is the rationale behind this move and how should we think about it impacting the P&L?

Moving onto Western Europe, can you talk to underlying trends in Italy, which has continued to be a solid market for you after the destocking issues of FY23? How are you positioning your footprint in Italy with regard to branded vs private label?

On this, you said at the Q2/H1 print that you were shifting away from private label production in Italy; can you provide some colour to this strategic decision and how we should think about your production footprint going forward? How should we think about the volume vs price/mix dynamic in Italy as we cycle through this change?

San Giorgio (acquired in 2023) has been a very successful acquisition for you in Italy in freeing up capacity across your footprint. Can you give some colour on the key positives from the acquisition and how this has helped alleviate supply chain pressures?
Still on Italy, can you talk to the current level of inventories? What is the sell in vs sell out dynamic in the market?
What would you say have been your learnings from the FY23 destocking situation and how are you better placed to deal with a similar scenario going forward?

Can you comment on your France business and add some colour to the H1 performance where you saw share gains in soft drinks? What are you doing on the ground re price/pack architecture and what is driving the robust performance?
The BeLux business has begun to ramp up; can you talk to early findings from the new business and the underlying trends you are seeing in the market?
What are your key areas of focus for the BeLux business? Can you give some colour around retailer contracts and how discussions closed in H1? How are you performing in the Snacks business?

Can you talk us through current momentum in the Netherlands, where you have been repositioning your portfolio with the exit out of energy and entry into RTDs? What are the underlying trends in the market?

In your International division there has been a high amount of volatility in the last couple of years. Can you comment on how you have navigated these headwinds and what underlying trends you are seeing in some of these markets such as Nigeria, Canada, Poland etc.?
H1 growth in International was strong, with Q2 benefitting from some inventory movements. How should we think about any unwind in H2?

Still on the International business, how should we think about the run- rate going forward? Clearly quarterly volatility it likely to remain part and parcel of the business, but can you comment to the sell- out trends you expect to see going forward and what the key drivers behind this are?
Looking to FY25, how should we think about the moving parts behind the \(+5 - 6\%\) net revenue growth? Can you talk us through the assumptions you have baked in for reaching either end of the range?

Can you comment on the impact of weather trends for your business? Q2 overall was "normal" with some moving parts around the edges such as the colder temperatures in Finland. How have trends progressed through July/August and to what extent is this reflected in your FY guidance?

Can you talk to your pricing outlook in FY25/26E? Clearly we will see price/mix moderate significantly after two strong years of growth. How has H1 pricing landed in the markets where you have taken price? Are you able to give some colour as to whether pricing will be broad- based or selective?

Can you comment on the level of down- trading you are seeing across your geographic footprint? Are there any markets to call out where this has been more severe? How confident are you in the resilience of the consumer?
On the bottom- line, you are guiding to \(+8 - 12\%\) FY25E EBIT growth. Again, can you talk us through the puts and takes behind reaching either end of this range?

You have previously said that the impact from acquisitions will have a negligible impact on the EBIT growth. Is this still the case? Can you comment to the clean organic growth you are expecting? Can we assume this is \(+8 - 12\%\) ?
How should we think about COGS growth for FY25E and FY26E? What are the moving parts behind this? What are the main pressure points from a COGS standpoint?
What level of hedging do you have in place for FY25/26E?
Is there any danger that you will have to give back pricing in any markets when the cost environment becomes softer?

Can you talk to Vrumona? What are your plans for the businesses and how should we think about the impact on the group in the short- term? Can you talk to the pricing you are taking in that business and the strategic rationale behind this? How has pricing landed with the consumer?

You have alluded to the fact that Vrumona, which you acquired in 2023, was perhaps under- loved by Heineken. Can you comment on the main changes you are looking to make in the business? Can you talk us through the capex plans you have in place?

And on San Giorgio, are you able to quantify the level of impact the acquisition has had on the group from an EBIT standpoint? Can you talk us through what exactly that business brings to Royal Unibrew and how you expect to leverage its production capabilities?
More generally, can you comment on the group's production capacity? What is your optimal level of utilisation and why? Can you comment on your capex plans and what areas you are targeting?

Looking slightly further back to the acquisitions of Hansa Borg (2022) and Solera (2021) - can you talk to synergies you have been able to realise and how these businesses have been performing? What is your end- goal with these businesses and what progress have you made?

Can you talk to your current partnerships? Can you provide more colour on the PepsiCo partnership and the impact you're seeing from this? What are the other main partnerships to call out and what have been the recent developments? How has the partnership with Diageo in Norway been developing?

In terms of capital allocation, you completed a 6- mth DKK250m programme in mid- August, and announced a further 4- mth DKK300m programme at the H1 print to end in mid- December. How should we think about buybacks going forward regarding quantum and timeframe?
Are there any markets or categories where you feel you are under- exposed and that would be of more interest should M&A be possible in the short- term?

You are guiding to long- term organic EBIT growth of \(+6\%\) to \(+8\%\) . What gives you the confidence in being able to achieve this? What levers can you pull across your existing markets to drive superior bottom- line growth?

Are you looking at further M&A opportunities in the mid- term? If so, are you able to flesh out a bit more the sort of targets you are looking at, and how you see the M&A environment playing out for the rest in the next couple of years?
When should the business start to reap the benefits to margins from the investment in higher margin categories and shift in the portfolio mix?
Can you talk about the long- term opportunities for categories such as RTDs, Cider and Energy? How large do you think these categories can become for the group?
Can you talk us through your mid- term capex plans?
Can you talk us through some of the product innovation you're most excited about, and which markets have the greatest opportunity?

Within beer you are focusing on the growing segments (premium, craft/specialty and low/no alcohol), rather than mainstream beer. How do you expect penetration of low/no alcohol to increase over the next few years and where is the biggest opportunity? How does this growth impact margins?
Within CSDs, your aim is to outperform the market within the low/no sugar category, how are you going about this?

Talk a bit about the investment you've made in IT systems in recent years? What more needs to be done in this area? Where do you think you're lagging peers or ahead of other FMCGs? Which regions/markets are ahead/behind the curve in this regard?

AI is clearly an increasingly important topic for governments, businesses, and societies. How has the wider AI debate evolved within Royal Unibrew over the past 12 months following the rise of generative AI?

What do you see as key opportunities within Royal Unibrew from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the beer industry?

Looking to the longer- term, maybe 3- 5 years forward plus, what category or growth opportunity or market are you most excited about in the business and perhaps in your mind isn't getting its fair share of attention when you talk to investors and analysts?

Short- term - what are the key questions?

Can you walk us through the new operating model with the establishment of the House of Brands? What is the rationale of the new business model and where do you see the key growth opportunities in the short/mid- term?

Are you able to speak to the current trading in Q3 so far? Q2 trading was broadly ahead of expectations and benefitted from the later Easter and generally supportive weather trends; what have you seen on the ground in key markets? Has underlying momentum continued?
Are there any key regions or brands to call out from a trading standpoint in Q3- to- date? What do you have planned from an activation standpoint?

OSG in the Americas picked up sequentially in Q2 to \(+4\%\) (H1- 1%). Can you talk to the driving factors behind this uptick and to what extent this benefitted from the recovery from the Q1 logistic delay in the US? Are there any brands where you are still seeing meaningful destocking headwinds at the moment?
Can you provide some colour on the logistic delays in the US in Q1? What were the key drivers behind this and was the headwind fully reversed in Q2 or is there still some benefit to come?

On tariffs, can you comment on what you have seen on the ground regarding stock levels? Are you happy with current inventory levels in the US? Was there any stock- build ahead of the Trump Administration's latest tariff announcements in July? That benefitted Q2?
Can you talk to Espolon and the current underlying momentum for the brand? How is Espolon performing relative to competition and are you able to comment on the promo environment in the US?

Staying on Espolon, can you talk about the roll- out of the brand and early findings from pushing global expansion? Can you give more colour on the capacity of Espolon and your capex plans in the near- term?
SKYY and Grand Marnier were both weak in Q2 in the US. Can you comment on the driver behind this and how you expect these brands to perform heading into H2?
More broadly on the US, can you talk to the consumer environment and to what extent you are seeing down- trading? How confident are you in your portfolio in a face of a weak consumer backdrop?

Can you update us on Jamaica and the current trends there, especially now you are no longer facing supply constraints? What is the consumer backdrop? How has the resolution to supply chain headwinds impacted your broader footprint eg the UK?

Are you able to talk about SKYY, which has been weak for some time now and is not included within your new House of Brands operating structure? Are you seeing any green shoots in the health of the US consumer which could drive a rebound in the brand? Or are you looking to reposition away from the more lacklustre vodka category?

In APAC, can you give some colour on the shape of OSG in H1? Q1 was strong, with OSG up \(+11\%\) , followed by Q2 at \(- 1\%\) . Can you talk to the moving parts behind the strong Q1 performance and the subsequent deceleration in Q2? What were the key drivers behind this?

Can we focus on Australia? What are the key growth drivers for the business at the moment? How has the on- trade been performing? Can you comment on Aperitifs momentum? How should we think about growth moving into H2?
Epsilon has been a strong brand in Australia and the RTD innovation has helped drive \(+10\%\) OSG for H1. Can you talk to the Epsilon RTD proposition and any further innovation you have done?
Elsewhere in APAC, can you comment on underlying trends in China and South Korea? What brands are driving performance there? Can you speak to the macro backdrop?
Moving to EMEA, can you comment on July/August trading and whether you have been able to sustain the strong momentum from Q2? Are you seeing any changes in the consumer environment there?
What is the pricing environment like in Europe? Can you talk a bit more about the promo intensity you're seeing for Spirits in Europe and especially what you're seeing in the Spritz occasion?
Which regions do you expect to be the key growth drivers for Campari in H2? Are there any categories/brands/markets that you are particularly excited about?
Is there anything to call out across your key European markets Italy, Germany, France and the UK from a current trading standpoint? How have your key brands been performing across these markets?
Are you able you give some colour on the Q2 de- listing in Germany? How should we think about the impact of this heading into Q3?
How is on- trade momentum holding up in key European markets? Can you comment on summer weather trends you have seen so far and how this has impacted your business? How has tourism momentum been?

Can we talk about Aperol which has been a strong success story for the group. How much of a growth opportunity does Italy represent for Aperol? Can you speak to the solid Aperol performance in the Americas in H1 with OSG of \(+8\%\) ? What were the drivers here given the US was only up \(+1\%\) ? How sustainable is this level of growth?
More broadly for Aperol, which key markets do you see being able to reach, or get close to, Italy's size either in terms of absolutes or in terms of PCC?
What are your plans for the Aperol brand in H2 to be able to sustain growth?
Can you flesh out where the increased consumption in Aperol is coming from? To what extent is this cannibalising from Campari?

- More broadly, can you update us on your production capacity? Do you have any supply constraints to your portfolio currently? Are there any remaining bottlenecks for brands or regions? Where are the main focuses of your capex plans in H2 and FY26E?- More generally, are there any other brands you would like to call out from a current trading standpoint that you are particularly pleased with?- Can you talk to tariffs and the impact you are baking into your guidance as it currently stands? To what extent will you be able to mitigate the impact?- Beyond the direct exposure you have to US tariffs, can you comment on second order impacts you are expecting to see across your global footprint?- Globally, where are inventory levels now? Are there any specific callouts from a regional/brand standpoint? Are you happy with current inventory levels in the US?- Can we talk about Courvoisier and your near-term plans for the brand? To what extent does the brand need repositioning and what is your vision for your Cognac portfolio in the short/mid-term?- Are you able to comment more on the stock situation at Courvoisier in the US and China?- How do you think the Campari group can bring the Courvoisier brand to reach its full potential?- Beyond Courvoisier, can we talk about further M&A? Your change in shareholder voting structure has set the group up well for "transformational" M&A. Are you able to flesh out what opportunities you see as potentially attractive? Are there any regions or categories where you most likely envisage Campari being active in M&A?- Re Wilderness Trail Distillery – what are your plans for the brand in the next few years? What sort of growth do you expect within the US Whisky market and how do you expect to benefit from this growth? Are you aiming to outgrow the category and if so, what levers do you believe you can pull to achieve this?- Do you have major capex plans for Wilderness Trail and how do you expect Wilderness Trail to operate alongside Wild Turkey? Are there any major synergy expectations or will they operate independently?- Can you talk about portfolio streamlining initiatives and what your criteria is when looking into brand divestments? Without being too specific, are there any low hanging fruits from this standpoint?- Can you talk to your cost containment programme and what actions you are taking? Are you on-track to yield a 50bps benefit on sales in 2025?- Can you talk to profit margin phasing for FY25E? Both A&P and SG&A were dilutive in H1 and you have spoken to H2-phasing of FY profit delivery; can you provide some colour to the moving parts behind the profit bridge and the shape we should expect to see through the quarters?Medium/long-term – what are the key questions?

When we look at the new House of Brands structure, can you talk through your mid-term expectations as to what the growth drivers will be across each 'house'? How should we think about brands not included under this operating structure?

How sustainable is the growth of Aperol in major markets like Italy, Germany and Switzerland? Where are penetration rates/per capita share levels in these markets? How much of your growth in these areas do you think is coming from new recruitment vs. higher levels of consumption amongst existing consumers?

Talk about your capital allocation priorities and your desire (or not) to engage in further bolt- on or larger scale M&A? What are the key factors, categories and geographies you'd like to address through any future M&A?

Talk about the strategic logic of establishing RARE - a dedicated division which will focus on the development of high- end brand propositions in the US and other Key global markets? What are the benefits you've seen to date and where are the long- term opportunities?
Talk about your expansion opportunity in Asia and especially the opportunity for Aperol and Campari to grow in China?

AI is clearly an increasingly important topic for governments, businesses, and societies. How has the wider AI debate evolved within Campari over the past 6 months following the rise of generative AI?

What do you see as key opportunities within Campari from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the spirits industry?

Short- term - what are the key questions?

Can you talk a bit about current trading and the underlying momentum across your portfolio? At the FY print you guided for FY26E OSG at a similar level to FY25 (+1.7%), with delivery to be H2- weighted. How should we think about the shape of the LSD top- line growth as we move through the quarters? What is driving the stronger second half sequentially?
Can we talk about the US and the underlying consumer environment you are seeing there? What are the key trends you would like to call out?
Given the ongoing tough macro backdrop, how are you deploying RGM initiatives to continue to drive demand?

Are there any key brands to call out from a current trading standpoint? We have seen weakness in the latest Nielsen data around Casamigos, while Don Julio has continued its impressive run. Can you walk us through your key US brands and what you are doing on the ground to keep momentum up across your portfolio?

Focusing on Don Julio, you delivered a very impressive FY25 with OSG of \(+42\%\) and shipments growing ahead of depletions. How should we think about the run- rate going into FY26E? Will there still be some uplift from retailer stock replenishment? Can you talk to the key underlying drivers for the brand and how sustainable this level of growth is?

Maybe turning to Casamigos, can you speak to the continued weakness there? How has the recent influx of celebrity- endorsed tequila brands impacted your brands and what you're doing to address the weaker trends at Casamigos?

Destocking has been a major theme/issue across spirits companies in recent years as the fall- out from the COVID super- cycle appears to have lasted for longer than expected. Can you comment on current US inventory levels at both the wholesaler and retailer level and given the moving parts around tariff- related stock- build, how should we expect inventories to develop through FY26E?

How are spirits performing vs beer in the US and what are the main drivers here? What have been the key performances to single out in the US from a brand standpoint? Are you able to give a run- through on the performances across categories?

Can you talk about Crown Royal Blackberry and the longevity of the brand? Clearly the activation was very well received, and we can see the slowdown in the latest scanner data now you are lapping the launch - but can you talk to underlying brand momentum you are seeing? What is the occasion for the activation and who is the target consumer group?
How should we think about further activations in the flavoured whiskey space?

Can you also talk to what you are doing with price/pack architecture and how you are leveraging brand loyalty with smaller pack sizes? What innovations have you done with Don Julio and other brands from a bottle size standpoint?

Moving on from the US, can you give us an update on your business in LatAm and talk to the current levels of inventory in the market? How should we think about destocking going forward? Are you able to comment on underlying consumer trends across the key markets in your LatAm footprint?
What have been your learnings from the Nov- 23 profit warning? How have you improved your visibility on LatAm inventory levels?

Can you run us through the latest trends across your key markets in Europe? Guinness has continued to be strong in the UK/Ireland; how sustainable is this level of growth for Guinness? How has tequila been received in Europe?

You have increasingly talked about focusing on Don Julio and Casamigos growth in Europe. Can you comment on current trading for both brands and how you see the tequila category in the near- term within Europe?

Both Northern and Southern Europe were weak in FY25, with strategic pricing in Scotch in Germany and new distribution model in France. How should we think about these headwinds in the near- term? What was the rationale behind both strategic moves?
Can you update us on the recent performance of your business in China and speak to the health of the on- trade channel and how you see this playing out in FY26E?
What proportion of group earnings do you think come from China once you adjust for the \(34\%\) associate stake in Moet- Hennessy?

Are you doing anything on the ground in China to re- focus your portfolio? Clearly the consumer environment has been weak for some time now and on- trade momentum has been weak. What are you doing to maximise your potential in what is currently a weak market?

Can you speak to current trading in India? What are the main trends there and how is premiumisation momentum holding up? Can you comment on the importance of India for you and how important the market is for group top- line growth in the mid- term?

Are you able to give us an update on Travel Retail Asia, which was weak through FY25 due to retailer inventory destocking? What are the latest trends in the business and how should we think about momentum heading into FY26E?
Thinking about Travel Retail globally, where are we now versus pre- pandemic in various regions? When would you hope to get back to pre- pandemic sales levels?
Can you talk to the changes in Nigeria regarding the new business model and partnership with Tolaram? Can you talk us through the new model and explain the strategic rationale for the change?

Can you talk about Guinness globally, which has been a huge success in recent years and increased appeal to both younger and female consumers, as well as expanding the occasion? Why has it been so successful and what has driven this
shift in taste and brand preference? What are the opportunities to replicate that in other markets?

Can you talk to your RTD offering, and specifically in the US as the category has notably outperformed spirits generally? How do you feel about your current level of exposure to the RTD category and how sustainable do you think the current levels of category growth in the US are?
How should we think about FX impacts on earnings into FY26E? Do you expect to see headwinds both translationally and transactionally?

Can you talk about the performance of some of your brand acquisitions like Aviation gin, Chase and Don Papa Rum? How have the brands been doing? Talk about the benefits Diageo has been able to bring to these brands?
Should we continue to expect some positive support to clean EBIT from the marking to market of earn- out agreements on these deals?
Equally, can you talk to the recent sales of some of your smaller brands like Pampero and Safari?

You have spoken a bit in the past about possible disposals within your portfolio. Are you able to provide any colour as to the type of assets you might be looking to offload? Can we expect these to be strategic/transformative or are they likely to be non- core?
How should we think about the impact of biological asset revaluations on your P&L into FY26E?

Can we pick up again on the debate around the resilience of premiumisation trends? We understand the long- term structural trend, that premium spirits are generally affordable luxuries and the relatively infrequency of purchase offers some protection from inflation pressures on disposable income relative to other consumer goods. BUT could we probe the vulnerability of some of those assumptions and wonder whether you have done any analysis or work to look at which socio- economic demographic have been driving premiumisation over the last couple of years and whether there has been a bigger propensity to trade- up from middle to lower income consumers than in the past?

Talk a bit about your COGS outlook for FY26E. Can you talk to the moving parts you are seeing within your business and where the pressure points remain? Can you comment on the tailwinds from lower agave price and how this filters through to the bottom- line?
How do you see the pricing environment heading into FY26E?
Can you talk to the current productivity savings programme and what are the main areas/regions you're targeting? How do we think about supply chain efficiencies within this programme?

You outlined the Accelerate Programme at the Q3 print and upped the savings target at the FY print to \(\) 625m\(from\) \ \(500m\) , with disposals likely to come in a more meaningful quantum. Are you able to give us any colour on where cost savings might be coming from? How should we think about the drop- down to the bottom- line?

You have also spoken to being able to deliver \(\) 3bn\$ in FCF annually; what levers are you able to pull to reach this target and what gives you confidence that you be able to deliver against this metric?
How should we think about buybacks going forward? Can you talk us through the criteria you use to determine the viability of capital returns via buybacks?
Can you give us any colour on the recent CEO move? When can we expect the group to come to a decision and what traits do you see as valuable in recruiting at the top level?

Can you talk us through the rationale of removing the mid- term \(+5 - 7\%\) OSG guidance at the H1 print? What were they key considerations behind this update and are you able to give any qualitative guidance on how you see the spirits industry and Diageo's performance in the mid- term?

Tequila has been a real growth engine for you and the industry in the US. The category has clearly slowed. How confident are you about the runway for growth in Tequila over the medium term and should we be worried that so much of your growth is so tequila dependent? How is the competitive environment developing?
Can you talk about the potential for Tequila outside the US? What markets are already seeing good traction for the product?
What proportion of your agave needs do you source externally and what proportion is from owned agave fields?

The pre- mixed cocktails (Ready- to- serve cocktails) space is 'hot' in the US, and you made some acquisitions in the space historically (Far West Spirits and Loyal 9), talk more about your strategy there given its an area where you clearly under- index? Do you need to acquire more brands to get your fair share of the category, or can you scale and roll- out what you already have?
What are your thoughts on India Free trade negotiations with the UK which has recently been agreed? What could it mean in the long- term for Scotch?

Premium Gin appears to be struggling to gain sustained traction in the US. How confident are you in the growth outlook for the category? How do you differentiate between your premium Tanqueray strategy and that of Aviation Gin?
Talk about your commitment too and the need to own a beer business outside of Guinness in Africa and other markets?
What does the recent change in chairman mean for Diageo? What will John Manzoni bring to the Chair role that is different to Javier Ferran?

Having a strong Digital and E- commerce strategy is increasingly likely to be key to the 'new normal'. You've been investing in consumer insight analytics as well as other digital tools. Can you talk in more detail about where you are on your digital/e- commerce journey? What areas need more investment and where do you think you're ahead of the pack?

How does the margin structure between E-commerce and traditional trade channels compare? Is the cost/investment required to get the right e-commerce listing increasing? Do you need to acquire your own e-commerce spirits platform in the way that Pernod Ricard bought The Whisky Exchange to really understand this space, or can you create it organically?

Diageo's has completed several bolt- on M&A transactions in recent periods including pre- mixed cocktails recently, as well as the larger acquisitions like Aviation Gin (2020) and Don Papa (2023). The addition of Casamigos (2017) in the super- premium tequila space was clearly a successful deal but why are you not creating more success stories in- house organically rather than through M&A? What skillsets are you missing or acquiring?

Talk about your moves into the low and no- alcohol space? You were early backers of brands like Seedlip but how are products like Gordon's O.0% fairing? How big an opportunity is this space for you and the spirits industry? Is it more profitable per serve than traditional spirits given the lack of excise?

What do you see as key opportunities within Diageo from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the spirits industry?
Are there any areas of Diageo's business which you believe are getting less attention than they deserve when you're interacting with investors and sell- side?
