Short- term - what are the key questions?

- The backdrop in China is clearly very tough, with FY25 OSG down -21% and ongoing headwinds in China Duty Free. Are you able to comment on the underlying trends in the market and your expectations for FY26E? What kind of run-rate can we expect?

- You said at the FY print that you expect a strong Q1 decline following the inventory overhang at year-end. Can you provide some color behind the moving parts here and what you are seeing on the ground from a retailer/wholesaler inventory standpoint?

- You delivered solid FCF of €1.1bn in FY25. Talk us through the moving part of your FCF development for FY26E and how quickly do you think it is possible for you to reach your 80% FCF conversion target?

- Can you comment on brand performances in China? Cognac/scotch have been weak, while Jameson and Absolut have been more resilient. Can you talk to the brand dynamics you are seeing and where the pockets of growth are in China?

- Can you comment on the US and the underlying trends you are seeing in the market? Towards the end of FY25 you benefitted from some stock-build around the tariff announcements, and you said you expect some inventory adjustments during FY26E. Can you give some further colour on the moving parts here?
- How should we think about destocking headwinds in the near-term and what gives you confidence that we are nearing the end of the down-cycle?
- How do you see depletion trends evolving over the next 12-mths? What are you doing at Pernod to mitigate the current market headwinds and drive a return to stronger growth?
- Can you comment on the state of the US consumer more generally? To what extent are we seeing downtrading and what actions are you taking on the ground to mitigate this?

- A key argument has been whether the Spirits industry, and alcohol more broadly, is in a structural or cyclical decline. What is your view on this? What gives you confidence that current trends are not structural?

- How are acquisitions in the US (Skrewball, Sovereign Brands, Codigo) performing? Where have been the out/under-performances relative to your expectations? It appears there has been some weakness in the Nielsen data in recent months? Is this a fair reflection of the performance or given their on-premise skew, is Nielsen data overly exaggerating the trend?
- What are you doing to turn around performance in Skrewball? Talk about your latest canned innovations for the brand.

At your recent US presentation, you outlined your national priorities for the US with 'power' and 'explode' brands. Can you speak to some of the key brands and how you are driving growth across both the more established brands like Jameson, Absolut etc. vs the higher growth potential brands such as Jefferson's and Del Maguey?
What was the criteria for categorizing the 'explode' brands? What excites you about these brands in the near/mid- term?
You also spoke to your wholesaler realignment process and RTM review. Can you comment on some of your key findings and what changes you've been making there over the summer?
India has been a very strong market for Pernod. Can you comment on the underlying trends in the market? What are the key drivers behind the strong momentum?
Still on India, how do you think about the balance of growth between volume and price/mix in FY26?

At the FY print you flagged excise changes in Maharashtra state which are expected to impact FY26 and predominantly Q1. Can you contextualize the headwind here and talk more generally to the regulatory/tax environment in your key states in India?

GTR was weak in FY25, down - 13% and driven by the suspension of Cognac in China Travel Retail. Can you comment on the latest developments here? Can you also speak to your Travel Retail business outside of Asia?
Can you talk to any other markets where you are seeing particular strength or weakness? Can you provide some colour on European markets and current underlying trends?
Can you talk to the main moving parts behind FX impact on EBIT and what you are factoring in for FY26? How much of an impact is Turkey having on FX?
Can you comment on the approach to taking pricing for FY26? The global environment for price is likely to remain subdued but which markets do you think have scope for pricing if any?

How are you thinking about elasticities in spirits? Have you seen deteriorations in any regions vs what you had expected? Are you expecting elasticity rates to be different going forward in any markets?

In part your US performance has suffered relative to Diageo due to your smaller position in Super- premium Tequila and relative to the market due to your smaller position in RTDs. Can you comment on your strategy in both tequila and RTDs? How are Altos and Avion performing? How has your RTD offering performed?

Can you update us more generally on your RTD strategy in the US? It's clearly a category which is still enjoying good momentum and you already have Absolut and Malibu RTDs in the space as well as more recently the launch of Absolut Sprite? Can you talk to momentum of the Ocean Spray vodka cranberry RTD?
Can we talk about A&P? You have guided to c.16% of sales at the group level, while this is more like c.19% in the US. Given your absolute spend was just 15.3%
of sales in FY25, can you flesh out you're A&P strategy and where you'll be pushing higher spend in FY26E and beyond?

Can you comment on efficiencies you are targeting for FY26E? What are the key areas of focus in your business in the near- term? How much of the new €1bn 2026- 26E efficiency programme will you be able to capture in FY26E?

There have been a handful of disposals in recent years, with further disposals such as Wines and Imperial Blue due in the near- term. Can you comment on your disposal strategy and how you think about non- core assets? What metrics do you use when assessing whether to offload brands/businesses?
You revised your mid- term guidance to \(+3 - 6\%\) OSG (from \(+4 - 7\%\) ) and organic operating margin expansion. What is driving your confidence in returning to this level?

You also expect to deliver €1bn in efficiencies from FY26- FY29 - can you comment on where within your business you expect to deliver on this goal? What are the key areas we should expect you to be driving efficiencies in? What will the phasing of these benefits look like?
What gives you confidence that the industry can return to these levels of growth especially given some risk that new Legal Drinking Age consumers may be moving to drink less than previous cohorts?
Where do you see industry growth coming from in the mid- term? Are there any particular categories to call out or regions? To what extent is India a key driver in mid- long- term growth?
Can you talk us through the changes Conor McQuaid has made since taking over leadership of the US business and how he is making that business more agile vs. history?

Regarding India, a Free Trade Agreement with the UK was reached in May- 25 and offers potentially significant upside for your business. How well- placed is Pernod to capitalise on this FTA and how should we think about what the India business might look like in 5- 10 years' time?
Which categories do you believe will drive medium to long term growth in China? Still primarily Cognac and Scotch or other categories including your local Chinese whisky business?
Can you talk a little more about the deployment of your digital transformation strategy? Where are you in the deployment process with regards to key digital programmes:
MAESTRIA (consumer segmentation tool)? VISTA REV- UP (promotional effective tool)? MATRIX (tool to optimize markets and trade spend)? D- STAR (salesforce optimization tool)?
How much more upfront investment is required to deliver these initiatives or is more about roll- out and adoption within the business now?

You've made some moves into the low and no-alcohol space with Cedars, Celtic Soul and your recent minority investment in Almae non-alc blue agave which was co-founded by Lewis Hamilton and Casa Lumber? How big an opportunity do you think this area is for Pernod and the spirits industry in general? How do you think about the medium-term risks that consumers may choose to just drink significantly less alcohol?

Can you talk a little about your capital allocation plans mid- term? Share buybacks appear to increasingly be a core part of that strategy. How should we think about buybacks going forward in mid- term?
Are there any areas of Pernod's business which you believe are getting less attention than they deserve when you're interacting with investors and sell- side?

Short- term - what are the key questions?

Can you comment on the latest developments around MOFCOM measures to impose minimum pricing commitments? Are you able to give us some colour as to the moving parts and how much of an impact you expect these requirements to have on your business? What are you doing in- house to mitigate the impact?
How should we think about the dynamism around the regulatory situation in China and can we assume the minimum pricing commitments are here to stay?
Are you able to comment on current trading in China and the ongoing headwinds in China Duty Free? How should we think about the market as we move through FY26E?
To what extent have you baked in a recovery in China Duty Free in your FY26E guidance of MSD OSG?
Can you talk to the underlying momentum in China aside from Duty Free? What have been the latest consumer trends you have been seeing there?

Can you comment on current wholesaler inventory levels in China and the ongoing cash pressures? You stated at the Q1 sales print that inventory levels were healthy at the end of June - have you seen any change to this? Are you confident in your current positioning and can you comment on wholesaler appetite to build inventory?

Do you think the China cognac category can ever return to the HSD/LDD growth we've seen in the past or given the lower China GDP outlook, are we now in a structurally lower growth environment for Spirits?
Moving to the US, how should we think about the shape of organic top and bottom- line growth in FY26E? Are there any key pockets of strength/weakness on a brand or state basis?

On tariffs, you are assuming a \(30\%\) EU import tariff to have a net €35m impact on your business. Can you comment on the moving parts behind this assumption? How should we think about the possible benefit of a lower tariff rate? How would this flow through the P&L?

You flagged that inventory levels in the US are at c.4- mths. How are you expecting FY26E to progress from a depletion standpoint and subsequently how should we think about stock- build / destocking as we move through the FY26E?

You saw a sequential deceleration in US Cognac depletions in Q1. Can you talk to the underlying trends you are seeing and talk to the differing depletions you've been seeing for VS cognac versus your VSOP, 1738 and XO offering in recent periods in the US?
What would you envisage a normalised year in US Cognac would look like? Are you able to give approximate underlying depletion expectations on a go- forward basis?

Can you talk to the promo environment in the US and what the competition landscape is currently like? At what point would you engage in promo in the US to gain share or are you fully committed to maintaining brand equity as a premium cognac?
Can we zoom in on VSOP and can you talk about your pricing strategy there and is there anything to call out on a state- by- state basis?
Can you comment on trading in EMEA? Are there any specific regional or brand performances which stand out?
Can you comment on the UK, which saw a weak Cognac performance in Q1 driven by negative phasing? How should we think about this market in the coming quarters? What were the drivers of the phasing?
Can you also talk to the launch of VS in South Africa and Nigeria? Are you able to flesh out your strategy there and how you see these businesses evolving?
Can we move onto Liqueurs and Spirits, and can you talk to the strong Q1 performance? Is there anything to call out across your key brands ex Cognac from a current trading standpoint?
You saw Q1 OSG in North America of "very strong DD%" - can you talk to the main drivers behind this strength?
Are you able to talk to the current consumer environment in Europe? Have you seen a deterioration in consumer elasticities at all and can you talk to the current promo/pricing environment there?

Can you update us on the cost pressures in your business from a raw material and broader supply chain standpoint? To what extent are you hedged for FY26E and how do you see the near- term outlook from a COGS standpoint with falling commodity & energy prices?
Can you talk about pricing plans for FY26E? What level of pricing are you likely able to take and how confident are you in the resilience of the consumer to accept these price increases?
Can you talk to your cost- cutting initiatives and your ability to potential find further savings into FY26E?

How is the business thinking about the potential for a pick- up in Travel Retail in Asia and elsewhere through fiscal 2026? Where are we now vs. pre- Covid? For how long to you envisage China Travel Retail headwinds to persist?
Can you talk about the new CEO appointment and any early findings? How do you think you can help effect a turnaround in momentum for the group and what gives you confidence in the Cognac category?

You removed the mid- term guidance at the FY25 results in Jun- 25, due to the ongoing tariff uncertainty, lack of macro visibility and continued weakness in the US. With the new CEO likely to establish a new roadmap in time, are you able
to give any colour on your qualitative mid-term expectations for the group and how we should think about the trajectory in Cognac top-line and margin potential in the next few years?

Clearly the big ongoing debate in Spirits is around whether the industry decline is cyclical or structural. What are your thoughts on the down- cycle in the context of history and what are your thoughts on the length of the cycle? How are you thinking about your business from a big picture standpoint and where you think the category will be in the mid- term?
What gives you confidence that Cognac will return to growth? Does the extremity of the down- cycle prompt a more proactive approach to diversification into other spirits categories?
How do you balance the trade- off between strong cognac demand and limited supplies of maturing inventory. What levels of cognac volume growth are sustainable over the medium- term?
You've stepped up marketing investment in recent years. Do you feel that investment is now at the right level and that spend will grow more in- line with sales going forward?

In the last couple of years, you have acquired a cognac house (Brillet- 2020) as well as a champagne house (J de Telmont- 2020). Can you talk us through the rationale for acquiring these companies and your strategy in Champagne? How long do you expect to have to invest in them before they turn profit making?
Are there still gaps in your portfolio that you are looking to fill? How do you think about further bolt- on M&A opportunities?

What do you see as key opportunities within Rémy from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?
Do you have any concerns that regulation (or lack of it) could influence the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly within the spirits industry?

Short- term - what are the key questions?
- Are you able to speak to current trading in Q3-to-date? Have there been any key developments since Q2 which are worth calling out or has it been more of the same?
- Can you comment on recent performance in the AFH and at-home channels? What underlying trends are you seeing? How are you thinking about trading into the key summer period?
- Similarly, can you talk to trading across your portfolio and any particular areas of strength/weakness across your categories?

- At H1 you reported FX-n revenues in Iberia down -1%, impacted by the transition from Nestea to Fuze Tea. Can you talk to the rationale behind this move and how you expect trading to develop through H2?
- What underlying trends have you seen in Iberia through H1? How have weather trends impacted momentum?

- Similarly, in Germany FX-n sales were down LSD in H1 with a recovery in Q2. Can you talk us through the shape of OSG trends YTD and whether you have seen momentum in Q3-to-date follow on from the better Q2? What drove the weakness in Q1?
- You also talked to headwinds from a sugar tax in France. Can you give some colour on this and what you are doing on the ground to mitigate the impact here?

- GB volumes have been pretty strong YTD, supported by innovation. Can you flesh out what innovations you brought to the market and how we should think about innovations more generally across your footprint heading into the summer?
- Are there any other key developments to highlight from your European business? How have weather trends been in Jul/August?
- Can we talk about Indonesia? Can you talk us through the rationale behind the SKU rationalization and for the focus on Sparkling and Tea? Why are these the main two categories to focus on?

- Are you able to talk to the weak Q2 performance where you saw volumes down DD%? What were the key drivers behind this and how has momentum fared in early Q3? What are the key headwinds you are currently seeing in the market and what you are doing to mitigate the impact of these?
- Still on Indonesia, can you fill us in on the latest RTM changes and the benefits you expect to generate from the new structure?

Can we talk about the Philippines? What have been the key findings since taking over the business? What are the low- hanging fruits from a synergy standpoint that you can realise in the short- term? How should we think about the margin outlook for CCBP?
What are the differences/similarities between CCBP and the Indonesia business?

For FY25E, you trimmed the top- line growth guidance slightly to \(+3 - 4\%\) (from c.4%) and maintained bottom- line growth of c.7%. What were the main reasons behind the slight trim to top- line? At the same time, what gives you confidence in still being able to deliver c.7% EBIT growth despite the weaker OSG outlook?
What are the key assumptions you are baking into your FY25E guidance with regard to key markets in Europe, Indonesia and Philippines?

How should we think about price/mix for FY25E? At what run rate can we expect CCEP to take price going forward after a period of higher pricing to offset inflationary pressures? Are you confident this will be accepted by the consumer?

Can you talk about the state of the consumer generally? You talk about the need to balance affordability and premiumization, how do you think about the promotional environment in your major markets in FY25E?

What underlying consumer behavior buying trends are you seeing from a price/pack standpoint in the AFH channel? Can you comment on the level of transactions relative to volumes in Europe and APS (Australia, Pacific & South- East Asia)?

More generally, can you walk us through the various strategic repositioning initiatives you have done recently? Clearly there was the SKU rationalization in Indonesia, but can you also comment on the bulk water exits in Australia/Germany/Spain, Beam Suntory in Aus/NZ and Capri Sun in Europe. Can you go into some more detail behind the rationale and timeline of these changes?
Do you have an end- point in mind for where you are comfortable with your portfolio positioning? Or should we expect rationalisation to be an ongoing part of the business?
You have guided to COGS per unit case inflation of c.2% for FY25E. Can you unpack the moving parts behind this and where you are still seeing stickiness on prices?
Can you talk about your Coffee business and how that is progressing?
How has your Energy portfolio performed in 2025 so far from a market share perspective? Are you expecting to see continued gains going forward? What sets your Energy offering apart from competition?

In terms of your geographic footprint in Energy, can you talk to recent launches and how you see the Energy business performing across your regions? How has Energy been performing in Philippines? Do you think you will launch in Indonesia or are the market dynamics as attractive as elsewhere for the category?
On Indonesia, and the Tea category, can you comment on the competitive environment there and the performances of both mainstream tea and flavoured tea? How are you positioned regarding pricing?
Can we talk about ARTDs and your exposure to that category? How is the Jack & Coke and Absolut & Sprite performing? Are there any other partnerships/RTDs coming?
Can we talk about your cost savings programme where you are expecting to deliver €350- 400m in FY24- 28. Where do you think the key opportunities are?

Can you talk a bit about capital allocation? You said at the CMD in May- 25 that M&A is unlikely in the next 2- 3 yrs, but with an attractive leverage profile, alongside a solid €1.7bn FCF p.a., are you remaining open to opportunistic M&A should the right opportunity arise? What areas would be appealing for you to engage in?

You are targeting 2.5x- 3.0x leverage in the mid- term. How should we think about leverage going forward? Is the middle of the range your goal? Can we think about buybacks in the region of €1bn to continue at least in the short- term?

How should we think about the CCBP business in the mid- term? Where do you hope to see this business ending up from a growth/share perspective? What do you think need to be the key changes in the underlying business to really unlock its full potential?

With two large scale acquisitions in recent years in Indonesia and the Philippines, can you set out where you think the current business will be in the next 5- yrs? Can we expect you park further M&A for the meantime and to focus on consolidation and establishing the existing business?

You talked at the CMD to "four and more". Can you flesh out what you mean by this? How should we be thinking about your c.4% top- line growth guidance in the mid- term and what are the drivers to push OSG beyond to 4% floor?

Within this, you have guided to \(+2 - 3\%\) growth in Europe, \(+4 - 5\%\) in AP and HSD% growth in SEA. Can you talk to the key drivers for each region and which categories you will be focusing on in key markets to deliver to \(+4\%\) ?

Can you talk to some of your key growth categories, namely Energy, Coffee and ARTD? How do you expect these markets to develop in the mid- term and which areas are you most excited about as we look out over the next few years?

You have also guided to at least €1.7bn in FCF per annum, driven by top- line growth, margin expansion and strong cash conversion. Focusing on cash conversion, can you talk us through what you can do to optimize working capital and investments? What are the key levers you can pull to achieve the €1.7bn?

Can you talk about the opportunity to improve per- capita consumption and your core brand presence in Indonesia over the medium term? Can you share a bit of the history there and how big the opportunity could be? Where are you on this journey?
How should we think about the evolution of coffee profitability and margins over the next few years? And where does coffee now sit in the pecking order of brands/categories within your portfolio?
Talk about the opportunity in the rapidly growing Energy space? How big could this category become? What do the economics look like there compared to group average or Sparkling?

It seems like every time we talk to a bottler about their relationship with the Coke mothership, they tell us it's never been so good. That's clearly reassuring but what do you think has really changed on both sides of the relationship in recent years to mean the system has become so much more closely aligned?

What do you see as key opportunities within CCEP from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?

Looking to the longer- term, maybe 3- 5 years forward plus, what category or growth opportunity or market are you most excited about in the business and perhaps in your mind isn't getting its fair share of attention when you talk to investors and analysts like us? In other words, what is the exciting bit of the CCEP story that we might be under- estimating now?

Short- term - what are the key questions?
Could you share your thoughts on recent trading? Is there anything to call out on the July/August trends?

Can you speak to current trading across your top priorities, i.e. Sparkling, Energy and Coffee? What are the key themes there and where are you expecting the key areas of growth to be within those categories?

Which regions/categories within your footprint/portfolio do you see more room for improvement and where are you satisfied with your performance to- date? What are the key areas to drive growth in H2 and FY26E?
From a margin standpoint - which categories and markets are underperforming and what can CCH to do to bring these businesses to group margin levels?
What are the main markets you are excited about for H2/FY26E?

Can you comment on pricing? You took pricing in several markets in H1, are you able to add some colour on how this has landed? How should we think about pricing for FY25E overall? What is the latest pricing environment like in inflationary markets such as Nigeria and Egypt?

Can you run us through the DRS landscape and which markets within your portfolio have the scheme in place? Are there any other DRS or sugar taxes expected in the near- term? How do you tend to price through DRS implementations and what impact do you typically see on volumes?
You have also disclosed that there are four more markets where DRS is expected to go live by 2028 - are you able to disclose where these are?

How confident are you in the resilience of the consumer? To what extent do you think the consumer can accept further pricing and what initiatives are you taking to manage the under- pressure consumer wallet? Can you talk to your price/pack architecture strategy?

You reiterated FY25E guidance with the H1 print with top- line growth of \(+6\%\) to \(+8\%\) and organic EBIT growth of \(+7\%\) to \(+11\%\) . What are the puts and takes to reaching top- end and bottom- end of both guidance ranges?
Can you talk about transactional FX and the importance this has on your organic EBIT growth?

Are you able to talk about COGS for FY25E and how you see COGS per UC developing? Can you talk to the moving parts within this and which areas within your cost base you are seeing a meaningful reduction in cost or stickiness?
What is the promotional environment like across your key markets? There have been some signs of a rise in private label products in some European markets of late. What are you seeing?
Can you talk to trading momentum by channel, and how we should think about Q3 given you are lapping soft weather comps across much of Europe?
Can you walk us through the key Established Markets and gives us a sense of underlying momentum? What are you focusing on in key markets Italy, Ireland, Greece etc.?
You have seen weaker trading in both Austria and Switzerland; can you talk to the main drivers behind this? What are you seeing in these markets regarding consumer sensitivity and buying behaviour?
Can you comment on your performance in Nigeria and specifically on your Sparkling and Energy businesses there and what the competitive environment is like?

Are you able to talk about European markets where the macro environment is more challenging, namely Romania, Czech Republic, Hungary etc.? What are you seeing re the consumer and what are your expectations for H2?

Volume in Poland were down LSD in H1, which was in part driven by the return of a key competitor after a period of absence. How should we think about near- term momentum as you continue to face competitive headwinds? How has your share performed and what level of share will you be happy with going forward?

Talk about the dynamics with your Egyptian business? How have you dealt with the currency devaluation? What impact is this having on volumes and end demand? Given you are now lapping the brand boycott situation surrounding the Israel/Gaza conflict, are we seeing some respite here?
What is recent trading like in Ukraine? Any changes in consumer behaviour you're observing given the widening conflict?
Can you comment on underlying trends within the Multon business in Russia?
Can you speak about the Finlandia acquisition (2023) and your plans for the business? You've been expanding the footprint in new markets? How is that developing?
Can we talk about Coffee which has become a priority category? What are the key opportunities within this category and how confident are you in your ability to execute successfully?
On your RTD offering, can you comment to the performance of Jack & Coke? Can you also comment on partnerships you have with Spirits players?

Can we also talk about the share buyback programme, which has been paused since Sept- 24? To return the full €400m by year- end requires you to be relatively aggressive in H2; are you still committed to returning the full amount in FY25? Can you talk to why we have been such a long pause in activity? How should we think about capital returns going forward?
At your CMD in May 2023, you upgraded the mid- term guidance for organic revenue growth to \(+6 - 7\%\) (from \(+5 - 6\%\) ). Can you talk us through the moving parts behind the upgrade?

What do you expect to be the main drivers in achieving this level of OSG on a sustainable basis? Can you talk us through your expectations across the divisions and also which categories you see driving the most incremental growth in the mid- term?
What are the main drivers of the 20- 40bps of annual margin expansion? To what extent will this be cost efficiency focused and what extent revenue growth management driven?
If your margin expansion exceeds 20- 40bps annually, will the profits be invested back into the business?
How do you think about the outlook for the Multon business? Do you see ongoing direct ownership of Russia assets as potentially problematic? Are you able to repatriate cash out of Russia?

Talk a little about how package architecture has evolved in your business over the last 10 years and how this enables better RGM (revenue growth management)? How much further scope is there for shifting consumers to smaller pack sizes in some of your more Established Markets?

Can you talk a little about your digital transformation within the group? Are you happy with your B2B and B2C offering? What is best- in- class and what needs more work? Is this an area which will require a step up in investment spend further in the years ahead or is it more about deployment and engagement?

Can you speak to M&A in the mid- term and what your appetite is for expanding your footprint in Africa? Is there any possibility that you could still participate in the CCBA operations in Africa or do you expect that business will definitely be IPO'd? (Reuters, 29 Apr, link).

Remind us of your capital allocation priorities? What do you consider the appropriate level of financial leverage to be? Are there potential M&A opportunities you're looking at in the mid- term? Remind us of the strategic and financial criteria you apply to potential M&A?

You've been involved in the coffee space for some time initially through Lavazza. Talk a little more about the skill set and business expertise you have within CCH to make you a credible competitor in the coffee space to the major operators like Nestle or JDEP? And update us on the roll- out of Costa Coffee across your geographies?
How should we think about the evolution of coffee profitability and margins over the next few years?
Can you talk about the opportunity Energy in a bit more detail and the different consumers and occasions you think can be targeted with products in this area?
Do you have the right offering to fully exploit the potential there? What do the economics look like there compared to group average or Sparkling?

Given the acquisition of Finlandia, could you talk in a bit more detail about what role you see alcohol playing in your business over the medium term and whether it could become a more meaningful part of your revenue base?
It seems like every time we talk to a bottler about their relationship with the Coke mothership, they tell us it's never been so good? That's clearly reassuring
but what do you think has really changed on both sides of the relationship in recent years to mean the system has become so much more closely aligned?

What do you see as key opportunities within CCH from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of AI more broadly?

Within the discount segment, can you talk to your strong Q2 performance where you saw +18% volume growth? What was the key driver behind this and what are you doing to deliver on your Discount offerings?

Talk more generally about the pricing environment across your portfolio. And the broader competitive environment given the brand laddering initiatives BAT is undertaking with Newport and Lucky Strike?
How should we think about combustible pricing for FY25 and into next year? Are you able to talk to on ongoing run- rate we can expect to see?

With the US- wide menthol ban shelved in Apr- 24, has there been any further development behind the scenes and how do you see this legislation under the current administration? Can we assume this is more a topic for the medium- term now?

In Vapour, the cease- and- desist order on NJOY is clearly a major negative development for your NGP business and follows a further failed foray into vapour with JUUL. Do you have any plans within the vapour category in the near- term or will you shift your focus solely onto Modern Oral?

Shifting to Modern Oral, can you talk us through the current underlying momentum for On!? What, in your view, has been driving the continued impressive growth rates, both for On! but also for the category in general?

Can you comment on the differentiating factors between On!, Zyn and Velo? Can you give some colour on the recent brand performances across the category and why Velo has been seeing such strong growth? What is it that differentiates Velo from On!?
Can you also talk about the PMTA for On! PLUS and explain the characteristics of that product? How has the launch of On! PLUS been received outside the US, namely in the UK?

Outside of On!, your smokefree oral business has been under pressure. Looking at Q2, Copenhagen shipments were down \(- 8\%\) and Skool shipments were down by \(- 9\%\) ; can you comment on the key drivers behind the weakness?

Are you able to give us some colour on Copenhagen and Skool share performance within Traditional Oral? Clearly the share performance you disclose is distorted given that Traditional Oral is ceding share to Modern Oral; but how are both brands performing against their like- for- like peers?
Can you talk us through the margin profile of your NGP products vs Smokeable?
Can you also comment on your holding in ABI? How should we view the remainder of this investment and the potential impact a further disposal may have on your credit rating?

Talk about your board seats at ABI and your ability to maintain those going forward? At what level of equity stake in the ABI business do your think you'd cross the threshold into having less influence and with that, the ability to equity account for the investment?

Can you provide some colour on your plans for your NGP business in the midterm? Vapour has been an Achilles heel for you, while On! has been strong and you are hoping to submit a PMTA for Ploom soon. When you look 3- yrs ahead, what will your NGP offering look like?
What will be the key drivers enabling the transition away from combustibles? What are the key milestones you need to hit to deliver against this target?

Are you likely to revisit Vapour in any capacity? With better FDA enforcement around illicit, how should we think about the run-rate of a clamp-down and what do you think the long-term penetration of illicit will likely settle at?

Can you talk a little more about your new heat-not-burn offering SWIC and explain what makes this product different to others on the market? Talk us through your timeline for launch and your plans on how you intend to scale this? How does this product fit alongside your JV with Japan Tobacco?
Are you concerned about PMI's entrance into the US with IQOS? How do you think about the potential for the heated tobacco category in the US?

You clearly focus a lot on your smoke-free business when we talk about the mid-term. Can you just give some colour on how you see your Smokeable business evolving over the next few years and what are your key goals for Marlboro going forward?

What do you see as key opportunities within Altria from the adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly? Associated with that what do you see as key risks to your existing business model from adoption of generative AI and AI more broadly?

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be

different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
